text:
The first step is to switch all, or as many vehicles as possible to electric.(this wont mean carbon neutrality, but it's a start.
The second step is to seriously research Nuclear Energy and renewables, and focus on improving them. 
The third step is to completely revamp the power grid to account for these changes. 

Just with these 3 steps already we have already removed over 43% of all carbon emissions from the atmosphere, and bought us a decent amount of time(give or take, 40-50 years) before the inevitable doom. Now that's not a lot, but it does give us a lot of extra breathing room to figure out the rest.

The fourth step is a lot harder, but I think we can make it work:
Decarbonizing the construction industry. This does seem a lot harder(considering just how much carbon is produced from the construction industry(while we can turn their gas vehicles into electric ones, we still need to release carbon to make cement and steel.) I think we can make it work, if we can make better machines that not only absorb carbon, but actually funnel it back into the system as something useful, like energy(without releasing it). This is a bit of a stretch but if we can get it to work, we can revolutionize every other industry. 

This step alone would extract 31%, bringing our grand total of extracted co2 down to 74%(buying us a combined estimate of 70-90 extra years)(I am just gonna stop with estimates because im not a climatetologist and these time estimates are terrible.)  Certainly not "Over" by any standards, but at least we're managing it properly this time and the bulk of the work is done.

Step 5: (14%) Remove emissions from the agricultural industry by going vegan or reducing meat consuption, or, alternatively, plant tons of algaes and natural biological co2 absorbers(hopefully mainly genetically altered ones) to cover for what isnt exactly as realistic as sort of a natural freebie. 

Now we have officially extracted 88% of our emissions from the atmosphere, we're almost there! 

Step 6: (6%)cooling and heating. With our electricity grid new and improved, it's safe to assume we can reduce our emissions there to near zero, heating is more of a problem; considering how many people prefer fireplaces and campfires, however; I think it might be easier to call on our good friend algae for this one :)


Now we have officially extracted 94% of our emissions from the atmosphere, I think it's safe to say, that if we follow this plan, we can save the climate! YAY!

text: Excellent video.  I like the balanced approach to climate change, as I have been telling everyone for a long time, that there is no single magic bullet here, but rather we need to do a lot of things, and one of those is deciding what we consume and what is important.  For example, choosing a product with a lower carbon release footprint is better than choosing one with a high carbon release footprint.  With the sheer number of people on the planet, if each one us did a single activity, that would collectively add up to a very large activity.  So, we need to work together, collectively, to solve this dilemma, and that includes reducing the carbon releasing activities that we are currently doing to more sustainable levels.

text: This is just wishful thinking.  I'm all for replanting trees, but the real problem is politics, not science.  There are many ways to address climate change, but each one of them requires the political willpower to make them a reality.  For instance, we should stop cutting down the tropical rainforests, but politically that is a non-starter for Brazil.  In the US, we should stop clear-cutting our forests for lumber, but that is the business model that the lumber industry uses.  Also, if we stop clear-cutting, then the price of lumber will go up, which is detrimental to the housing industry (and the economy), which is a big NO-NO for US politicians.  So, yes, planting trees would help, but getting anything done (on a large scale) is next to impossible.

text:
So no, it will barely do anything to hel stop climate change. Because first of all, the problem isn't only that we cut down our forests, the main problem is that we use fossil fuels. And massive amounts of it.

Trees are temporary. Even if they live for hundreds or even thousands of years, their carbon is still part of the carbon cycle. Fossil fuels, however, are semi permanent and stores carbon for millions if not billions of years. So if we want to solve climate change, we need to find a way to store that exces carbon, permanently. Trees are just not good enough.

text: I did this calculation once. Ok, first of all, NO. You aren't sequestering carbon from the atmosphere when a tree absorbs it, not permanently at any rate. Because when the tree dies, it decomposes and returns the carbon.... except even worse, SOME of it becomes METHANE when it decomposes, which is a form of carbon which is 100 times as effective as a greenhouse gas as the carbon dioxide that it originally took out of the air, so in the long term, actually it makes it worse. I think the best you can do is actually to grow a plant that puts the carbon compounds it produces into a solid form such as a grain or beans, which can be stored without decomposing. But as for the calculation, here's the deal. The human species uses 6*10^20 joules per year of energy. Meanwhile, 1% of the entire land area of planet Earth is dedicated to growing wheat. And the wheat harvested has a caloric value, or rather a joule value, of just over 10^19 joules. So there's still a factor of 60 difference between the energy stored in the crop yield of 1% of the land on Earth and the energy used by humans. Now not ALL of the energy used by humans is burning fossil fuels and puts CO2 into the air, but probably at least half of it does. So assuming that factor of a half, that would mean that to sequester the carbon dioxide put in the atmosphere by man by growing plants, you would have to dedicate 30% of the land area to growing wheat (or something equivalent, but wheat is probably about as efficient as it gets) and then not eat that wheat or do anything with it but just store it. Just so you know, that amounts to about 20 billion tons of wheat per year. Bottom line, you just can't do it with plants. They are not efficient enough solar collectors and converters of carbon dioxide to solid carbon compounds so as to sequester them.

text:
I don't think planting trees is helping us a lot in the near future. Trees need time to grow, and since climate change is already accelerating we have to plant now trees for an already changed climate: The trees in the Canadian forests e.g. have to struggle already with hotter summers than ever, and many of them will not survive. Dying trees release CO2, and young trees do not bind much CO2. We simply don't have the time to wait another 30 years when the trees planted today will start to have a real impact.
We have to cut down the trees which can't survive the climate change and to haul them out whilst they are good enough to be used as construction timber of for furniture (and so try to prevent the release of their CO2 for at least another 30 years or so). But their is another carbon sink in nature we could use: Bogs or moors. Humans have drained most of them already - only about 3% of the global land area are left. But they trap currently still twice as much carbon as all forests together do. They do grow only slowly, but the carbon stays trapped for thousands of years.
So we have not only to stop the draining and peat digging, but also start the rewetting of moors we can still rescue - and perhaps even build new ones.

text: Part of planting trees is using an intelligent plan. In some areas, we need to plant native species that support wildlife and improve habitat. In other areas, we need to assure that we are planting in environments meant to support trees. In communities and cities, we can plant deciduous trees to help keep houses and buildings cooler in the summer to reduce energy use and reduce carbon production at the same time, but these trees would still allow the sun to warm homes and buildings in the cooler months. We can use evergreens as natural windbreak in residential areas and on farms. In other areas, we need to plant native grasses or other plants that are accustomed to a dryer environment and are good for habitat.

text:
Sorry to break it to you all, but planting a ton of trees will do almost nothing to help climates change AT BEST.  At worst, it will destroy natural ecosystems and rob the most vulnerable people of their land and resources.
Natural ecosystems that these tree plantations are replacing already sequester carbon... just as much as these trees, but also provide a stable, biodiverse ecosystem.
Restoring and protecting natural ecosystems, especially wetlands and rainforests, is much more important.  Trees actually PLANT THEMSELVES in the areas they're needed most.  Making tree plantations to "fight climates change" is a fool's errand.

text: One trillion trees seems like a lot.  Each month, I donate to a couple of charities (Eden Reforestation and trees.org) that plant 700 trees, mostly in Africa and developing countries at 10 cents per tree.  There are 1.3 billion people in the developed world, so at this cost per tree, each of us would need to contribute approximately $100 to plant 1 trillion trees.  This money not only plant trees, but would provide jobs, restore degraded environments and increase the chances that these people can remain in their countries instead of becoming economic migrants.

text:
1 All Plants need Carbon to grow. So do all animals. So planting more trees will improve our world.
2 Increasing Co2 leels makes trees grow faster and they spread faster meaning more trees which results in trees growing in places  where they   couldn't grow previously like deserts and high mountains
3 Trees can't stop climate change since multiple factors contribute into it, like Water vapour in the atmosphere, Ocean circulation, Solar and the 3 Milankovic cycles. 
4 Since Co2 and Water vapour share the same IR absorption wavelengths we don't know how much it actually contributes to the greenhouse effect.
5 No average temperature of the earth actually exists because we don't have thousands of evenly distributed thermometers scattered all around the globe. Gavin Schmidt said in 2015 that the global average temperature is just an estimate not a measurement.

There is NOT "climate change", this is a bullshit!

Plus the so called "greenhouse gas effect" is proven wrong, forever by law of physic:
Wien displacement law (that is where the T^4 relation with insolation comes from).
Measured temperature in the Venus atmosphere from VERA-2 and VEGA landers. 
At 49km, (1bar) they show a temperature of 339Kelvin - which is easily calculated from Earth by; 
Tv=âˆœ1.91 x Te 
339=1.1756 x 288 
This is final proof that there is no Greenhouse effect on Venus or on Earth.
This formula collapses the 'Greenhouse effect' and proves it does not exist; 
Te = âˆœ0.523 x Tv
Te = 0.85 x 339 
Te = 288.15 Kelvin 
The surface temperature on Earth is easily calculated - from Venus. The fourth-root of the TSI difference times the temperature in the Venus atmosphere at 1atm = Earth's temperature! 
The equation formula works on the Titan as well:
Titan  Tt =âˆœ0.01089  x Te
             Tt = 0.323 x 288

This gives the calculated temperature on Titan at 1 bar as 93 Kelvin.
Measurements by the lander Huygens in it's descent trough the Titan atmosphere, show that the temperature at 1 bar is around 90 Kelvin.

text:
WANT TO HELP SAVE THE PLANET?  Here are 6 things every individual can do to save the Earth:
1.  Go VEGAN (food, clothes, accessories, toiletries, furniture etc.)
2.  Consume products LESS and become an INFORMED consumer.  
   -  Don't buy anything new (except if necessary, like medicine or contact lenses).  You can buy basically everything USED or make it yourself.  
   -  Do your RESEARCH before buying anything.  Many products are destroying the environment via the extraction of raw materials, the production process, transportation etc.  Also production lines are full of human labor abuses.  Do your RESEARCH if you must buy something.  Remember, your purchase of a product acts to support that company and everything that went into that product.
   - If you don't know 100% how a product was made at each and every step, then do NOT buy the product.  You could be unknowingly supporting the extinction of orangutans in Indonesia (ex. palm oil) or the destruction of the Amazon Rainforest (ex. beef).  No joke.  Stop buying products unless you are 100% informed.  Don't be selfish.  You  don't need most products.  Buy it used at eBay/Craigslist/Goodwill or make it yourself instead of contributing to the destruction of the planet.
          - Check if the product has any certifications, such as:  RainforestAlliance, FairTrade, RSPO - Roundtable on Sustainable Palm Oil, USDA Organic etc.
   - Stop buying via Amazon!!!  It has rampant human rights abuses that have been clearly reported on many times, including abuses and neglect during COVID-19.  In addition, despite some of its 'climate pledges', Amazon has a terrible negative impact on the environment.  Think factories, energy-usages, packing for all of those boxes, carbon emissions for the trucks that deliver them etc.  If you buy via Amazon you are supporting human rights abuses and environmental degradation.  Do you really need that product?  Just buy it used or at least directly form the actual company.  Don't be selfish, be responsible.
3.  Go plastic and packaging free.  Don't buy anything with non-compostable packaging, or that's made of non-environmental material.  If you do, make sure it's recyclable and recycle it properly.
4.  ADOPT and REDUCE family sizes.  Humans have overpopulated the world and are destroying the environment as a result.  The human population is almost at 8 billion.  We need to intelligently and voluntarily work to get our numbers down to at least half of that.  It is a very personal issue, but please consider adopting children instead of creating new children.  If having biological children, consider smaller family sizes.  
   - Donate money and/or volunteer at organizations that support women's rights and literacy.  On average, women's illiteracy rates are inverse to the number of children they have.  I.e. the number of children a woman has decreases as she becomes literate and more educated.  Here are some ideas:  Room to Read, World Literacy Foundation, Malala Fund, UNICEF, Campaign for Female Education (CAMFED), Afghan Institute of Learning, Invest in Girls, Educate Girls, AGE Africa, Asante Africa Foundation, Sheâ€™s the First, Forum for African Women Educationalists (FAWE).
5. VOTE and become politically informed.  Make sure to stay politically informed and pressure your local, state and national representatives to support issues and legislation that save and protect the environment and species.  VOTE during elections.
6. Use only RENEWABLE energy and use LESS of it.  
   - Buy carbon offsets from a reliable company for your yearly energy usage.
   - Stop flying unless absolutely necessary (and buy carbon offsets if you do).  Walk, bike, ride a velomobile, use public transportation instead of gas-powered cars.
   - See if your energy company has an option for you to buy green energy or support green energy initiatives.
   - Install your own renewable energy sources, like solar panels.
   - Be conscious throughout your day and use as little energy as possible.  Ex. instead of turning on the heat, just wear a few more layers and close the windows.

We can save the planet if everyone just does their part.  Everyone please act!

Check out this presentation for more information on human impacts on the environment and what you can do to help:  https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=YP83Qz6TabM

text: Still hoping to find a video that does the honest math on CO2 and trees. Not this one. There is no mathematical value in saying that the trees can capture up to 1/4 of human emissions. Totally incomplete. Says nothing about CO2 emission trends, tree life-cycle etc. One tree can  only take so much CO2 during its lifetime. What happens to that biomass eventually? Unless we store it somewhere (fossils), it is a zero sum game. How much oxygen draws entire Amazon out of the air? How many more Amazons do we need to plant to have any real impact (not just feeling good about ourselves or some questionable green awareness this will generate)?  Is there enough free and fertile land that can be used to plant N new Amazons? If not, how much is attainable? What is the real impact? There might be some answers to these obvious questions, but somehow the kids fascinated by these projects as well as the adults cheering them on don't seem to be even aware of the questions. Of course, videos like this one acknowledge that planting trees is not enough. But honestly, give me the exact numbers. Is it worth it at all?

text:
The albedo affect-
That doesnâ€™t mean that all forests cool the planet, however. Researchers have known for decades that tree leaves absorb more sunlight than do other types of land cover, such as fields or bare ground. Forests can reduce Earthâ€™s surface albedo, meaning that the planet reflects less incoming sunlight back into space, leading to warming. This effect is especially pronounced at higher latitudes and in mountainous or dry regions, where slower-growing coniferous trees with dark leaves cover light-coloured ground or snow that would otherwise reflect sunlight. Most scientists agree, however, that tropical forests are clear climate coolers: trees there grow relatively fast and transpire massive amounts of water that forms clouds, two effects that help to cool the climate.

text:
If only it were quite so simple.
Haphazardly planting trees without considering which trees are planted in which area will very likely mess up the balance in biodiversity and flora diversity in said areas. Furthermore, I daresay that one giant and ancient tree stores more CO2 than several saplings combined. It takes time for planted trees to reach their full potential. So yes, knocking off the whole tree deforestation is a decisive necessity, but when it comes to planting, I still feel like we should let nature do what it's always done best, and focus more on globally becoming carbon negative in the very near future.

Some exaggeration there!
20 Million Trees = 4 Million Tonnes, i.e. 20 Trees absorb 4000 Kg. of  CO2 or One Tree takes up 200 kg of CO2. 
That happens only if the hard wood is preserved without any kind of decay for many many decades! Most of the biomass in plant growth return to atmosphere as CO2 or Methane in a matter of years if not months.
Instead of your calculation, 25 kg per tree per year should be a good estimate for permanent carbon sequestration.

text:
I have a brilliant idea! Let's reduce the amount of water vapor in the atmosphere! Since carbon dioxide accounts for 9% to 26% of the greenhouse effect and water vapor accounts for 66% to 85% of the greenhouse effect, we can stop the deadly global warming much more effectively by reducing the water vapor in the atmosphere. So here's the plan:

We get a bunch of plastic garbage bags and duct tape them together to form a layer over the Earth's oceans to stop the evaporating water from reaching the upper atmosphere. At the same time, we begin collecting as much rain water as possible and put it in sealed containers, stopping it from evaporating back into the atmosphere. Great! We've bought a ton of time! During this time, we switch from fossil fuels to nuclear to completely eliminate all CO2 emissions. We then peel the layer of garbage bags off the oceans and throw it in the garbage.

Well boys, we did it. Climate change is no more.

text: Says Fact and it's not a Fact. We experienced this amount of heating several times so it has been there before. For example: The heating from 1910 until 1940 was similar to the heating from 1975 till 2005. The cooling between is like the cooling we have now. We will be experiencing a warming again probably from 2035 till 2065. CO2 will rise exponentially and can not prevent the cooling. Trees were not the main cause for storaging away CO2. Because the stay at the surface they could be consumed by animals and fires and avoided to being stored away. Seashells and clams are stored in huge amounts of oil and carbonated rocks like limestone and chalk. They are the main reason we have so low CO2 levels. I am not saying planting trees is wrong, it's cool and all but since the earth is greening because of rising carbon levels in the atmosphere it's not necessary. Plants grow faster when there's more CO2 and they survive droughts better because less water can evaporate du to the reduction of stomata, little openings on the plant that lets CO2 in. The most effective way to get more plants is to increase CO2 because they grow faster, which is a common practice in commercial greenhouses. But climate change can't be defeated by that. What does that even mean? Climate change is not controlled by simple factors but several factors and CO2 is just a small greenhouse gas which is less effective in warming the planet the more there is, called the logarithmic effect. Water affects climate the most in all its forms. As ice it changes the albedo, as water it absorbs heat, as clouds it deflects heat. The wish to reduce atmospheric CO2 leads to extinction of all life because plants need a certain minimum amount to grow. If Crustaceans and Clams store more of it underground trees will die first and life after it. In the end clams can't build their shells anymore. Most people think they do the right thing but haven't researched this topic enough. Fun fact. There was a time where North Canada had subtropical climate. Today there are no trees. If we could warm up the climate enough we could plant trees as far as the poles. Tropical arctic was a thing. And don't worry about the polar bears. They don't need ice to survuve. They need seals. Seals don't need ice to survive, they need fish. Fish don't live in ice but in the ocean, and that exists almost everywhere. Another fun fact. When we had all 6 Billion trees we had climate much warmer than today, several times throughout human history. Why is everyone afraid of higher average temperatures? I would be afraid of lower temperatures. Because there is a rule: the colder it gets the drier it is, the warmer it gets the wetter it is. That means when the temperatures are higher plants can grow everywhere where there were deserts before. That is why the Sahara desert was once a huge savanna 8000 years ago. But in the end it looks like we will have another big ice age coming like in the last 400.000 years. We are in an interglacial period, do the warmest part of an ice age. And we already had the highest average temperature like 8000 years ago. Even that highest average temperature is lowering with every interglacial period. And during those ice ages there were kilometer thick ice sheets covering Europe and Canada. If that happens Billions of people will die because the earth becomes more inhabitable. And during those ice ages CO2 levels were at 180 ppm. 30ppm above the amount where plants start to die.

text: Okay, cool. But if we go the rout of synthetic biology, the resulting organisms are gonna have to be tightly controlled. Plant-adjacent things that are better at photosynthesis, all else being equal, will out-compete and displace just about every other photosynthetic organism we have. Quickly. And the long term result of that could be as bad as the current climate crisis, or worse. If they get out into the world, there'll be no getting them back under control. And if they escape control, we could be looking at a planet with no non-synthetic plants left, too little atmospheric carbon, and too much oxygen to sustain life as we know it.

text: More trees are never going to be bad and much more timber put in construction would trap co2 and trees have a wonderful aesthetic for people and wildlife. However the host of this video makes a false assumption that human activity creates too much CO2 for the atmospheric system to cope with. It is not possible to quantify the effect of co2 on the temperature of the atmosphere. Fluctuations in temperature would cause fluctuations in humidity which would cause fluctuations in cloud cover which would cause fluctuations of solar energy hitting the Earth which would cause fluctuations in wind and fluctuations in ocean currents and fluctuations in precipitation and fluctuations in weathering of rocks and fluctuations in biomass as well as many other fluctuations. All these fluctuations interact causing further fluctuations which in turn cause further fluctuations and so on. There are other effects that seem to be ignored by climate alarmists such as volcanic activity, solar activity, core activity, galactic activity which also interact with the other fluctuations. All these fluctuations mean quantification of the effects of co2 are not possible. Apparently we are approaching the orbital cycle that would bring us into the next glaciation period soon and there is some concern that anthropogenic co2 emissions might delay it.  If the host were correct in his wild assumption then I think most of us would prefer to deal with a few feet of water in New York than a mile thick ice sheet.

text: The only issue I have with videos like this one (on climate change and phosynthesising organisms) is how little credit is given to the seas and algae... Trees are big and colorful and protect big animals, but the sea area/ volume is so much bigger (even though they are basically wet deserts). Oceans hold within themselves a huge amount of Co2 and many of the very teeny tiny (and yet very important) microorganisms that are important for the ecology of the world. Not to mention that, after a forest has reached peak development (generaly), they at best become neutral carbon emmiters (yes, plants also release Co2, albeit in smaller ammounts than they sequester), plus, a forest has animals, and animals release Co2. so, its not that easy... but most definitely, trees are important but are only a part of the grand solution.

text: Â @Jernej BlatnikÂ  We do not full coverage today either, in the sense you mean it. And now cherry-picking the 100 years of your choice is not very convincing either, because you completely ignore the exponential effect of positive feedback. Combine it with an increased forcing each year as we put out more and more CO2 ourselves, you have a rapidly increasing temperature curve. 1.5Â°C change since 1850 is our best case scenario.
author: Xellos

text:
Â @XellosÂ  I'm not cherry-picking. 1900-2000 is only century that we have temperature data. We don't have data for whole 19th century. Global temperature from 1850 til today has risen by 1Â°C. In 170 years! But alarmist are saying, like you, that it rise by another 2Â°C, some even say by 4Â°C, in the next 80 years. I think that 1.5Â°C global temperature rise when you double CO2 level is by far most realistic hypothesis/theory. And measured data show the path of this theory. When will we reach 560 CO2 ppm level? Probably by year 2100. And problem with CO2 is that is losing ''heat capturing'' with volume. When CO2 level will be 1120 ppm it will warm only by additional 0.7Â°C. When 2240 ppm additional 0.35Â°C. But, by this point we are talking centuries away and who knows what technology will bring by this point.
The positive feedback you are talking about is still just a unproved hypothesis. This hypothesis show earth's atmosphere in such a basic picture that it borders on a cartoon.
author: Jernej Blatnik

text:
â€‹Â @Jernej BlatnikÂ  Unproven hypothesis? https://agupubs.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/pdf/10.1029/2010GL045338
And this is only one that I have at hand, which discusses feedback. Feedback itself is proven beyond a doubt. It is now researched how strong it will be (hence all the computer models)
Positive feedback is actually the simplest topic in this whole debate. Here are some simple facts, proving feedback without any complex science required.


CO2 increases temperature


Increased temperature causes ice to melt
Dead plant matter and methane bubbles are stored below the permafrost
In some areas perma frost melts now, releasing CO2 from dead plant matter and methane from the bubbles
Ice is white, ground below ice is darker than ice
Darker surfaces absorb more light, absorb more energy, heat up more
Release of gases and heated up floor further increases temperature


Increased temperature causes ocean water to expand
Water property to absorb CO2 weakens, as temperature rises, because it loses density
Less absorbed CO2 in the ocean increases CO2 in atmosphere, leading to an increase in temperature


Please feel free to argue any of these statements. If you cannot, you cannot argue feedback. And yes clouds increase albedo, and are one of the points still contested as far as I know. They also capture more energy which was reflected by the ground, and we do not know if increase in temperature will have any effects on cloud generation, or in which direction (more or less clouds) so there are a lot of unknowns in this area.


I have never heard that CO2s effect weakens. Please provide me a reference for this, as this would be interessting to know
It does not change the argument itself though. If it is true, the papers will have included it in their math.

text: Well, carbon dioxide is a big deal. Our present problems with climate change started at 1860 because that's the beginning of the Industrial revolution. I've read that the process of photosynthesis in plants stops when the level of CO2 drops below 150 parts per million and when it stops the plants starve to death. The life as we know it, on this planet, is plant based, so..... no plants - no life, no us. So basically in cold 1860 we all were on the brink of extinction (remember - 180 ppm), but that's okay, as long as climate then was a little cooler than now. And speaking of carbon, scientists determined that during last Ice age that lasted over 200,000 years there were some periods of time when levels of CO2 were over 700 parts per million (almost twice of what we have now). So.... don't worry, be happy.

author: Goos

text: Â @GoosÂ  Yes, trees are certainly helpful in the short term, for humans currently living. i make the implicit assumption that we will not reduce the CO2 concentration for multiple generations - that may be wrong. If we get the CO2 down in a couple of decades, the short term effect is exactly what was needed to reduce the maximum. It's probably worth planting trees, but the idea of doing it on a large scale still scares me, just from the math: There is a limited area we can use for trees. Increasing the number of trees increases the combustible biomass, and the connections between burnable areas. In the long run, that results in few large wood regions that can not be extinguished if ignited (as space for fire breaks is used up).
author: Volker Siegel

text: Â @Volker SiegelÂ  I am sorry I forgot to specify it but what I was implying is there would be way less forest fires when the temperature goes down. This may not be the case in temperate zones but in places near the equator like the Amazon rainforest, the moisture prevents fires. I kinda agree with you about planting trees in places like America but there's no way a fire could start in places where there is plenty of water and moisture.
author: Goos

text: Â @GoosÂ  We explicitly expect climate change, so I make no assumptions about rainforest regions staying wet. That's part of the risk. But independent of that, the point about how moist wood burns is very interesting. Moisture prevents starting fire. But it does not prevent fire from continuing. Let's assume we have a dense wood next to a burning warehouse that provides energy for ignition. If there is a flame front, it radiates heat into the wood that is in front of the flames. That can be easily enough to dry plants. A fire in a dense dry wood with ground fire and crown fire is really intense. And rainwoods do burn. (I'm not trying to be pessimistic, and I am not. Fire physics is just so interesting...)
author: Volker Siegel

text: Â @Volker SiegelÂ  Of course, a fire started by a person or by accident due to human activities can lead to fires but the chance of a natural one happening are far less. I am not saying to just fill the entire world with forests, but at least 1/3rd of a country's land must be covered with vegetation of some kind. We could mark these new patches of forests as reserved to prevent human-made fires

text:
Also, not every country is lucky enough to have somewhere a tree can thrive. Some countries are too arid while others may be too cold or mountainous. Then there are countries where the land trees can thrive is already mostly covered with trees already. Then there's the problem with island nations that don't have enough space, like Fiji. Just a blanket statement like "we should plant 1 million trees in every country" doesn't take into account these issues.

text:
You can't do anything about temperatures and nor can trees. Cosmic rays affect cloud formation and thus surface temperatures. The intensity varies as sunspot activity affects the size of the heliosphere.  Also, magnetic and gravitational fields of planets divert the paths of cosmic rays towards or away from Earth so natural cycles appear to relate to planetary orbits. text: Trees have existed for about 370 million years. They did nothing to stop the Permian Extinction event 252 million years ago, when rising CO2 levels eliminated about 90% of sea life and 70% of terrestrial life. They also didn't seem to help during the Paleocene-Eocene warming event (~56 million years ago), which saw a global increase in temperature of about 9ÂºF. We are currently in a low-temp environment, since we are exiting an ice age. Temperatures will eventually swing upward again, and neither trees nor humans will stop it. The only way for us to combat climate change is to find ways for us to ride out the worst effects--adapt or die.

text:
This isn't addressing the issue at all. 

Atmospheric carbon is increasing because we are taking carbon that was previously outside of the carbon cycle and emitting it when we burn fossil fuel. The trees we grow may take that carbon out of the atmosphere, but as you pointed out it returns to it when it rots or gets eaten. 

We can plant all the trees we want, but the only way to take carbon out of the carbon cycle would be to produce non-degradable carbon products, or otherwise storing carbon products in an area where they wont be used. 


This most likely means making plastics, which aren't great for the environment for other reasons. 


Furthermore, this doesn't consider water vapor is by far our most abundant greenhouse gas, which is often the bi-product of our most ecofriendly forms of energy production such as nuclear fission reactors. Looking into a way to decrease atmospheric water may also help areas struggling with drought. Especially considering we are currently in an ice age, the tale end of it, and should be prepared for climate change to turn previously frozen ice into liquid water and water vapor; snowballing (Pun intended) our problem. 


There is no easy answer.

text:
I was expecting this to be the usual IOTBS debunking scientific misconceptions instead of perpetuating them. In terms of acting as carbon sinks, trees do very little compared to diatoms. (A type of microscopic photosynthetic eukaryotes). Diatoms account for HALF of all photosynthesis. Trees are less than 10%. Trees are important for other reasons, but as carbon sinks, they are not a solution. 

As for electric cars, they are certainly not good for the environment. Traditional cars burn fossil fuels at the point where they are used. Electric cars burn fossil fuels at a power plant far away, and they have to use a lot more because a lot of energy is lost in transmission and charging. On the other hand, since we don't see any exhaust (which is mostly water droplets by the way) we feel good about it.

text: I wish you would have talked about hugelkultur and coppicing . If we cut trees down and bury them in hugelkultur beds, as they decompose the carbon gets locked up in the soil. High carbon content is basically what makes good top soil which would help us plant more trees. And if we built very tall hugelkultur beds you increase the surface area of the land which also means more trees. And if we plant trees that coppice well we can do this very fast because if you are familiar this is a process of cutting trees down to the ground in the winter and trees that take well to this will send new shoots up the following spring. This process actually makes trees live longer and can produce a ton of biomass very quickly as some trees can send up shoots that grow more than 6 feet in a year or two. Combining these two with reducing emissions and growing our food in a polyculture permaculture system also using these beds the way Sepp Holzer did actually would solve climate change without the need to engineer trees.

text:
That's not entirely correct. A lot of electricity comes from renewable sources depending on country, some countries produce no electricity with fossil fuels at all (Bhutan). And even if we were to use only fossil fuels for our electric cars, a few large power plants are always more efficient than millions or billions of small engines, because they can always run under perfect and preplanned conditions and not waste as much energy on heat and acceleration/deceleration on each stop light.
But even then, you completely ignore that fuel doesn't just magically pop into existence at gas stations. All the energy (most of it electricity for heating and machines) that has to be spent on pumping the crude oil out of the ground, transport it to the refinery either by ship or pipeline, then run it through all steps necessary to process and clean it (which uses a lot of cobalt and lithium btw) and then carry it halfway across the country by truck just to be pumped into a tank under the gas station. All that is energy spent and carbon dioxide emitted that isn't even calculated into the emissions of the cars that use said fuels.
Compared to that, the power line losses and losses in charging and discharging the battery are almost negligable in terms of percentage of energy wasted.

You are mistaken and here is why.
Humans and our livestock now account for 96% of the land vertebrate biomass on Earth.  Only 4% remains in everything else (i.e. wild mammals and birds).  When humanity takes over the few remaining resources that currently supports that 4% (e.g. turning Indonesian forests into Palm plantations) there will be nothing left to take from nature.  We will have hit our carrying capacity and biodiversity on Earth will be at its lowest level since before the Cambrian. 

This is on track to happen within the next 300 to 400 years.
Once humanity hits that Malthusian Trap the lives of future generations will be immeasurably worse off.
Â 
Watch this video by Paul Macready (skip ahead to the 8:30 mark) to have a graphic representation of what is happening.

https://youtu.be/eneJXqmh3g0


And here is a reference paper to back up what I am claiming:
https://doi.org/10.1073/pnas.1807019115

text:
"Cutting those trees down and either burning them or letting them decompose just puts that carbon back in the atmosphere." And how, pray tell, do you want to stop plants from *dying*, then *decomposing*? People keep dodging the simple fact that most of the carbon sequestered by plants ends up back in the atmosphere once the plant dies. But sure, keep planting trees to clear your conscience.

And while we're at it, nature has had billions of years to perfect RuBisCO and hasn't managed to make it better. Furthermore, trying to "evolve" a better RuBisCO by "injecting" it into rapidly multiplying bacteria sounds idiotic when you think that cyanobacteria ("blue-green algae") have already been doing that for literally billions of years (at least 2.1 Ga). So, good luck with that.

The inconvenient truth (shut up, Al) is that we need to stop injecting more carbon into the carbon cycle by releasing carbon that has been sequestered into fossile fuel. But that would hurt the economy and thus, everyone would lose money, ergo, no one wants to do that.

text:
Giiizmo Agreed! Panting trees sequesters carbon during the lifetime of each plant, potentially decades or centuries depending on the species. While death and decomposition is inevitable, it buys humanity a little bit of time to decarbonize and at the same time provides habitat to mitigate loss of biodiversity. But youâ€™re right, itâ€™s not enough on its own.

Perhaps Rubisco hasnâ€™t evolved to be more efficient because there has never been a need to adapt to a truly carbon-starved environment. Plants have bounced back from numerous modern ice age cycles and although atmospheric CO2 has dipped below 300ppm during glaciation events, they have managed to bounce back into balance in interglacials. 

Until we build a sustainable, low carbon economy, we will continue to consume resources faster than they are replenished. 

We can do nothing but burn stuff until: 
- We canâ€™t grow enough crops to feed us all
- Run scarce of fresh water because alpine glaciers have melted in the hope that desalination technology will provide enough for people in those areas

Or,

We can invest and clean up our food, energy and transportation systems, saving us:
- Millions of lives in premature deaths by respiratory and cancerous diseases caused by pollution each year
- A future beyond the year 2100 which no one thinks about today. Future generations will likely have to deal with todayâ€™s carbon for thousands of years.

A green economy is inevitable, most people just havenâ€™t realized it yet. I just hope we wise up and elect rational leaders before weâ€™ve really messed things up.

text:
For anything to act as a carbon sink, it has to grab the carbon from the atmosphere and then hold on to it, fairly permanently. 
The micro biota of the ocean does just that, as it uses the carbon dioxide to build itself and its shells, then dies and sinks to the ocean bottom, where the carbon in those corpses lies there until subduction of that part of the sea floor gets it belched out again through volcanoes. [See https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=BAvQ3t4ueZw]
However, trees hold onto carbon only so long as they're alive: when they die, the decay process liberates that carbon back into the biosphere. So trees can only be a temporary solution, unless you create a large enough forest, and it's never cut down or allowed to burn, and it's ever replenished. (The Earth's peat bogs, because they also do that sequestration, actually hold more carbon right now that all the forests.)
The bigger problem, though, is that this works only on carbon dioxide. The looming release of mega amounts of methane from the melting tundra of Siberia, Alaska and Canada won't be reduced by either ocean biota or land-based plant-biomass. This is when the Earth's oceans go from living blue to deadly purple and extinction yields its scythe across the planet.

author: Gwendolyn Farms

text:
Yeah, keep talking. 

Lots of children's enthusiasm, turned into political something that has nothing to do with environment. 

Sending children to the UN. I call it child abuse. 

I don't trust the black lady either. "Women empowerment," -- there we go, steering away from environment into politics. The very thing the UN is so good at. 

Trees do not consume CO2 in the long run. In the short run they do, but then they decompose, and it all goes back. 

Sure, a massive planting of trees will consume lots of CO2 for a while, but when the forests are grown, the old trees die as fast as new ones grow, so decrease in CO2 levels drops to 0. 

Instead of planting new trees, better protect old ones. I just saw a documentary on Borneo -- one of the oldest forests in the world, dying under the axes. With all the animals and plants in it. To be replaced by a tree farm. Great! 

It seems that the real carbon sinks are not forests, but bogs. Peat moss, if maintained properly (which is not difficult), accumulates with no visible limit. But there isn't much noise about that. Perhaps because nobody really wants an inexpensive solution.

Btw, has anyone looked at the graph at 5:40? China as a CO2 polluter is way ahead if everyone else. Almost twice the US (which is next). Yet no one mentions it. Why? Because politics.

Synthetic biology -- sure, a wonderful pie-in-the-sky. Maybe millennia from now, after spending quintillion of dollars, people will eventually come with something. Probably not. 

We have to stop producing CO2 in such numbers. Easy to say. The reality is: we will not. The core of the problem is not CO2. The core is that there are almost 8 billion people on the planet. The rest is consequences.

So far all I see is everyone begging for money. The UN, the reforestation people, the scientists working in synthetic biology, governments, women empowerment organizations, etc. OK, let's say they get all this money. Will it get better? Nobody cares. My prediction -- it won't. Governments will encourage destruction of habitats with one hand, while taking money "for reforestation" with another. 

Others will continue with "We have to provide children with some ideals, so they will be all rah-rah about the future. So we can manipulate them."

Never mind that former rah-rah enthusiasts grow into "I don't give a damn" cynics after realizing how they have been used, again and again. There is a new sucker born every day. Literally.

I just found out (don't know whether it's true or not) that hybrid cars emit more CO2 than regular ones. If this is false, then manufacturers of regular carsare  manipulating us. If it is true, manufacturers of hybrids did for a long time. Either way... 

Nobody, except a tiny minuscule group of people, gives a damn. 

Sic transit gloria mundi.

text:
The logistics involved in planting enough trees just to make modern society carbon neutral requires the re purposing of millions of acres of agricultural land. Re planting enough trees to make the Earth carbon neutral would mean not producing enough food for most people, leading to massive famine.

It's uncertain if planting the trees required would really fix the issue, since our current estimates assume things won't get worse. We've messed up our climate to such an extent that climate change has become self-fulfilling because of feedback loops. Humans have pushed the ball down the hill, and its gonna roll regardless of if we keep pushing it. The most planting an ass load of trees would do is slow down the deterioration of our climate and MAYBE in the VERY long term help reverse the damage.

I don't mean to sound negative here, but selling a be-all and end-all solution to climate change is giving people the impression that climate change isn't an incredibly complex topic that cannot be approached from a single angle. Any solution to climate change will require changes not only from ourselves but from the systems we live under. There is no way to fight climate change without fundamentally changing our economic and social models away from consumerism and money-hungry expansionist corporation.

While the aforementioned may make it seem that climate change is an insurmountably challenge, the truth is it's a lot easier once you accept that climate change requires such massive changes, because you become aware of how many allies you have: supporting labour rights activists, pushing for pro-ecology & pro-workers rights legislation, deplatforming climate "skeptics".

The sooner we accept politics and climate change are undeniably linked together, the sooner we can start fixing this mess.

author: KuruGDI

text:
Coral is better than trees at sequestering CO2.  Consider the density of a  1 cubic foot of wood then 1 cubic foot of lime stone.   Limestone is heavier.  Limestone is what's left when coral dies.  I.e., they leave behind a skeleton made mostly of calcium carbonate.  CaCO3.  So, if we breed a more acid tolerant coral, or genetically re-engineer their absorption of carbonic acid (their source of CO2)  we'd could save the planet without pissing of 3rd world countries.


And besides - developing countries know not to clear cut and they do it anyway.  So - make tougher coral.  And we'd probably want to make their rate of reproduction go up with lower pH.  Or slow down with rising pH so we don't mess up the ecology of the oceans too much.

author: Arjen B

text:
The problem with trees is they're a temporary solution. The Amazon fires were intentional because people wanted space. And they make a point, we can't just impose on less developed countries to store the carbon for us while it's getting in the way of them becoming more developed.

We need a solution that stores well and we aren't tempted to burn for energy. But as far as i know we don't have one. Sure we can slow down but it's not like the world can just magically store that carbon if we go slow enough.

Until we find such a solution we're just wasting money and energy putting a bandaid on it. Alternative fuel sources are our current best bet, if fossil fuels stop being the most economical fuel source then we can turn some trees into charcoal to store it and call it good. But we're not there yet

text: I applaud the effort of #teamtrees. 21 million planted trees sounds great, but you can't ignore the videos of improper planting depth, spacing, species and terrain. I don't expect half of them will survive beyond saplings. If people really want to do some good, instead of following another YouTube trend, how about volunteer for the Forest Service? They do the dirty work of managing our forests in order to prevent these mega-fires that we've been seeing in recent years. I worked for the USFS with large crews that cleared brush, dead trees and fallen limbs as well as planted new trees. With the numerous programs the USFS has ran for decades to inform and educate the public, I can't fathom why #teamtrees didn't team up with them in the first place.

text: I love this. Trees = great. But as someone currently working in land conservation and in partnership with federal and state land managers, I wish this pro-trees conversation could include a little more nuisance. I'm so tired of hearing that we need to stop cutting down trees. My work centers largely on fire mitigation and invasive species removal, both of which involve cutting down trees FOR THE GOOD OF THE PLANET. We cannot find enough funds or enough people to do this important work of keeping our forests and ecosystems healthy and it's a problem no one knows about. If you plant a tree in an over-crowded forest or plant an invasive tree, it could be more detrimental than doing nothing. I also get that this might be too much nuisance when our world is burning, but I reserve the right to be annoyed by it.

text:
Â @Stefan The RainbowPhoenixÂ 
1. Negated by modern reactor design
2. Irrelevant. Nuclear energy =/= nuclear weapons and modern reactor designs are even more divorced from the technology used to enrich uranium to the point that it can be used in nuclear weapons even more than outdated reactors are
3. Negated by modern reactor designs and proper safety precautions
4. Negated by modern reactor designs and proper safety precautions
5. Completely false. Nuclear energy is thousands of times more efficient than any form of energy per ton of raw material
6. Irrelevant. A modern nuclear plant can be established essentially anywhere a traditional energy plant can be, which are already situated far from population centers to begin with. This is actually an issue with most forms of green energy, not nuclear. Wind, solar, hydroelectric, geothermal all require being situated in specific environments. Nuclear does not. 
7. False. When comparing efficiency of the energy produced and the amount of it, given the establishment of infrastructure nuclear quickly far outpaces the cost of establishing other means of harvesting energy.

Wake up. Nuclear is the only option for humanity's future.
author: Rockzilla1122

text: Â @Rockzilla1122Â  What can be asserted without evidence can be dismissed without evidence. Unlike your answers, the reasons to oppose nuclear energy from the website that I linked are supported by evidence.
author: Stefan The RainbowPhoenix

text:
Â @Stefan The RainbowPhoenixÂ  https://whatisnuclear.com/recycling.html

https://whatisnuclear.com/isotopes.html#enrichment

https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nuclear_meltdown, read under other reactor types. This goes for your worry that somehow a reactor will just magically give everyone cancer if it's running efficiently and safety precautions are in place. By the way, you realize fusion reactors would also have to abide by those same principles to be safe for human health as well, right? The output of fusion includes alpha and high-energy neutron emission, but if it is running as it should, just as with a nuclear fission reactor, the risk posed is negligible. 

Here's a series of sourced data sheets that disprove your preconceptions about the cost of nuclear energy vs its output. 
https://marketblog.files.wordpress.com/2008/09/variable.jpg

https://www.world-nuclear.org/uploadedImages/org/info/Economic_Aspects/us-electricity-production-costs-95-12.png?n=4287

https://ourworldindata.org/exports/death-rates-from-energy-production-per-twh_v1_850x600.svg

https://images.squarespace-cdn.com/content/v1/56a45d683b0be33df885def6/1528909327579-HWKW6IYAV0HWSL9HXNUD/ke17ZwdGBToddI8pDm48kL3VKmwKI3leYB51VJjLFB8UqsxRUqqbr1mOJYKfIPR7LoDQ9mXPOjoJoqy81S2I8N_N4V1vUb5AoIIIbLZhVYxCRW4BPu10St3TBAUQYVKcgK5SGg9Ovb1yloBBOHcruw_mYLfAhRzzgArFCB07Dw0L8n4JypuoE5Tg6Wg5Oyvs/Material+Throughput.001.jpeg

https://www.energy.gov/sites/prod/files/styles/borealis_photo_gallery_large_respondmedium/public/2019/03/f61/Capacity%20Factors%20for%20Utility%20Scale%201200x630-01.png?itok=fJ8kQeNr

https://i.pinimg.com/originals/3f/96/f5/3f96f5c96eb95f8ad081ad4d81315dd6.jpg

Not only does nuclear energy clearly outpace all traditional forms of energy extraction from fossil fuels in every metric, it does the same against 'green' energy sources as well.
Heres a fun fact, did you know that the production of solar energy panels is actually very harmful to the environment? The extraction of rare earth metals required to form the delicate pieces of technology that go into panels causes sweeping pollution and the destruction of natural habitats, as well as poor health for the workers exposed to it, typically in 3rd world countries in Africa that are already suffering through poverty and pollution.
Did you also know that all that concrete they have to produce to support that solar infrastructure makes its own carbon emissions? That's right, concrete outgasses carbon dioxide as it ages. It actually makes up a lot of our emissions each year. Concrete, however, is necessary to live in a modern world, but nuclear energy minimizes the need to add more of it than is required.

Nuclear energy, when done with a modern, 21st century approach, is cleaner, more reliable, more cost effective, safer, and all around the only realistic option when compared to any other form of energy production.

text: We should cut down more trees and invest in mass timber and energy.  Protected forests which are not cut down costs the economy and the tax payer.  Managed (cut down) forests provide a monetary incentive to plant more trees.  The more trees planted means the more money from harvesting them.  Building with mass timber cuts down (haha) carbon emissions from mining and cement manufacturing along with creating long-term storage of carbon.  Waste from mass timber (small branches or sawdust) can be turned into renewable energy which reduces our dependance on fossil fuels.  Tree harvesting could be planned to create wide fire breaks.  Having large fire breaks will reduce the total area burnt from large forest fires.  This reduces carbon emissions, but also decreases damage to property and infrastructure.  Monetizing forest management and not 'saving the trees' is the best way to reduce carbon in the atmosphere.

text: I know these comments are going to crucify me on a burning pyroclastic flow, but Iâ€™m sick of every video being about climate change. Surely there is more interesting science out there, perhaps more theoretical physics and abnormal biology. Convince me that not only is climate change as bad as itâ€™s made out to be, but that these â€˜solutionsâ€™ we hear so much about wonâ€™t detrimentally alter daily life. Obviously climate change is real, but why is it such a problem. As an Arizonan with scientific dreams I have noticed no change in temperature here, in fact our temperatures have nearly leveled out to nearly mid-west levels. My biggest concern, however, is still the social impact of such radical changes implied in stopping climate change. It has vilified America, possibly the most free and prosperous nation ever to exist, and made socialist programs more prominent in free nations. I like the tree planting solution, but all economic plans that â€˜revolutionizedâ€™ the fight against climate change have made nations with horrible working conditions and an over abundance of oil processing plants more prominent. Convince me that climate change could irreversibly destroy the planet within 10 years or so, convince me that we should ban all CO2 producing power plants, convince me that we should put polar bears before personal freedoms. Iâ€™m open to discussion! Iâ€™m sure many solutions and counter arguments are available, enlighten me.

text:
The video starts with a lie and labels it as fact. Regardless, the climate doesn't need to be saved. Nor does the planet. What we do need to do is stop polluting this planet. Because all that garbage ends up in our food at the end of the day. Now... allow me to share with you my findings:


1. Our species went through multiple ice ages and global warmings. The current global warming started approximately 12,000 years ago. That's how the last ice age ended and the current geological period, the Holocene, began. This warm and cozy climate won't last forever. Interglacial periods last between 20,000 and 60,000 years. So, we have between 8,000 and 48,000 years until the next ice age.

2. The rate at which the sea level is rising now is much lower compared to how it rose between 12,000 and 7,000 years ago â€“ a period in which the sea level rose by 197 ft (60 m). Look up the Early Holocene Sea Level Rise if you want to learn more.

3. The climate is always changing. There is no such thing as a stable climate. If you want to learn more about the "stability" of the climate, you might want to look up:
â€“ The 8.2 Kiloyear Event
â€“ The Little Ice Age
â€“ The Year Without a Summer (1816)

4. Chaos Theory tells us why the behavior of some systems is unpredictable (chaotic). Even simple systems can exhibit chaotic behavior, like the double pendulum, for example â€“ https://youtu.be/U39RMUzCjiU. No one can predict the climate.

5. Computer simulations of chaotic systems have no predictive value because the initial conditions can never be measured with sufficient accuracy. Such simulations only generate pretty pictures on a screen. Again, no one can predict the behavior of chaotic systems. Because â€“ Chaos Theory!

6. Compared to water, COâ‚‚ plays an insignificant role in the global greenhouse effect. Because â€“ and I'm not making this up â€“ 95% of all greenhouse gases is water vapor. 

7. COâ‚‚ is not a pollutant. COâ‚‚ is plant food. Almost all the oxygen in the atmosphere is a byproduct of photosynthesis â€“ a process by which plants use light energy to produce glucose from COâ‚‚ and water. Without COâ‚‚ plants die. Without plants, we die. COâ‚‚ is used in the food industry, for example, in the production of carbonated beverages like: beer, soda, sparkling water etc. COâ‚‚ is also used in hospitals, for example, in laparoscopic surgery. There are real pollutants out there we should be worried about and COâ‚‚ is not one of them.

8. Compared to astronomical factors like solar activity or the Milankovitch Cycles or terrestrial factors like volcanic activity, human activity has an insignificant effect in the long term evolution of the climate. We cannot start, end, or prevent ice ages or global warmings. We're not that significant.

9. This may came as a shock to you, but we're actually in the middle of a 2.58-million-year-old glaciation â€“ the Quaternary Glaciation â€“ look it up!

10.  There are many scientists who disagree with various aspects of anthropogenic climate change. One of them is Ivar Giaever, Nobel laureate in physics, who essentially said Global Warming is pseudoscience â€“ https://youtu.be/TCy_UOjEir0. Freeman Dyson said that "Climate Change predictions are absurd" â€“ https://youtu.be/fmy0tXcNTPs Wikipedia has a List of scientists who disagree with the scientific consensus on global warming, but it only contains the names of those scientists "who have their own Wikipedia article." Keep in mind that science doesn't work by consensus. Science isn't a democracy. As Carl Sagan put it:

â€œScience is more than a body of knowledge. It is a way of thinking; a way of skeptically interrogating the universe with a fine understanding of human fallibility. If we are not able to ask skeptical questions, to interrogate those who tell us that something is true, to be skeptical of those in authority, then, we are up for grabs for the next charlatan (political or religious) who comes rambling along.â€


Other reasons that might make you think twice before you join this climate religion:
â€“ carbon capture
â€“ carbon credits
â€“ Al Gore

text:
Please, no. Planting trees is a feel-good "solution" that can even be harmful (destroying steppes in east Europe). Not to say that all the wood will need to be stored and never burned / composted. Last year with my father we've collected and planted over 1000 acorns over two weekends (16 man-hours of work including roasting bacon) in a difficult terrain, that's 0.1$ per tree in minimum wage, assuming half of the acorns sprout. It's a sad world when people decide based on decisions of others and how would others judge them instead of thinking for themselves.

author: Andrew Austin

text:
=>> FFS guys, as much as I love me some greens, Trees are not the solution. trees capture the co2 and turn it into long chain sugars like cellulose. alas, trees decay, as fungi and bacteria and a large host of other organisms attack the dead wood, they break down the sugars and turn it back to co2
=> A tree say typically lives 50years (absorption period), and decays back in like 5 years (everything gets released back into the atmosphere). for this capture method to work we need to plant exponentially larger number of trees.  
=> Fossil fuels are made by organic matter (say trees) piling up in large quantities and in an era where there were not as many species around to decay them quickly, and subsequently getting buried. that way,  the carbon got captured and stayed in the ground in stable forms (coal, oil & gas). we are digging up and burning that stuff, planting the whole landmass of the planet still wouldn't send what we dug up back in the ground.
=> [unless, say, we capture co2 (with trees or otherwise), turn it into some long chain and stable form and pump it back deep underground, you know, like extracting and using oil, just in reverse. alternatively we could just stop digging up more of something we could not put back in]
=> "Maybe technology of the future would help us make this more efficient?" NO, thermodynamically, you are reducing local entropy, which means the total entropy has to go up. converting co2 back to oil takes considerably more energy than we got by burning the oil to get energy and co2
=> ah, a side note, bulk of the co2 capture and oxygen release of the plant is done by algae growing over the oceans, just spray nitrogen rich fertiliser in the seas and algae will go absolutely crazy, way more cost effective and practical. alas as algae decays it tends to create huge oxygen minimum zones which kills anything in the waters that needs oxygen, so basically, screw the fish

I read another article where the author said itÂ´s not convincing for him that 97% percent of all scientists agree on the topic climate change, its more interesting and scary because science is not so agreeeing in any other point... ItÂ´s strange for him that not many scienists even try to see it from another angle. For example the Temperature isnÂ´t rising because of the CO2 levels, maybe itÂ´s the other way round.
I like trees and IÂ´ve planted a few myself. I try to save the enviroment with walking and public transport, not producing to much waste and seperate it, but this has nothing to do with climate change for me. I never was really convinced, maybe with 14 when I learned the first time about it, but the deeper you dig into the topic the more complex it gets. I am sure that humanity has an impact on climate, but I donÂ´t know how strong. I think the surface change of our planet has more to do with worlds climate than some ppm CO2.

text:
Â @BBÂ  It seems that your idea of a black woman planting trees and empowering other women is something like they reunited at her nice house, chanted some hymns, drank herbal tea with pastries and then went to some nice place to watch men planting trees.
In Kenya, empowering women, going against deforestation, meant risking your life and be beaten up by police. Seemingly you don't know Wangari was a PhD, nor that she had active political participation, again including aggressions and jail. Ever read her biography?
https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wangari_Maathai
You are underestimating her as Churchill did with Gandhi. Except that you aren't Churchill.
About the race/gender thing, it's amazing (telling?) that you take it as a personal offense, as if it were a nonexistent issue, to the point of doubting this whole channel teaching of science. Yes, telling, more than amazing.
Take a look at CrashCourse History of Science. Race and gender bias is present everywhere, and impacts science things to the point that many women active and important in science were simply suppressed from the accounts, by considering them as mere secretaries or auxiliaries of research. Also, the non white male collaborators or discoverers or expeditionaries. 
Please also consider than a Peace Nobel Prize requires a quite different system of qualifications, unless your opinion about that award is the same as Sheldon Cooper's. Einstein revolutionized physics, but people can live perfectly without ever knowing of his work. Salk saved many lives, yet he didn't risk life and limb to do it. Wangari changed millions of people's lives, at risk of her own, and deserves recognition. A pity you take that as an attack on your personal dignity.
author: MarÃ­a MartÃ­nez

author: Gnorts Mr Alien

text: Â @BBÂ  Boy, you're really projecting, aren't you? When did I accuse anyone of racism or discrimination?
author: Gnorts Mr Alien

text: Â @BBÂ  I mean I think you are ignoring the fact that colonialism and the ideas of it have fundamentally effected just about every country and culture in the world. As such, you can have ingrained subcouncious behaviors that you don't realize produce not okay behavior. You conciously can believe in equality in all forms, but subcounciously could still think of and are more comfortable thinking that a white man would be someone of great importance then someone else. It's something that you are exposed to from childhood that results in you creating an image of what "normal" is. A good example would be when people complain about having characters be of a certain race for "no reason". When someone makes that complaint, it is because in their mind, normal/ default is white, so anything deviating from that needs to have a reason, it can't just be that way because the world is filled with many different types of people, it needs a reason. It is also important to know why that idea may be seen as normal. Suburban populations tend to have a larger ratio of white to non white individuals. This stems from several factors such as bank redlining towards neighborhoods and individuals of color as well as social and wealth inequality that existed since the countries formation. It's a positive feedback loop, as subcouncious behaviors can build up and lead to concious behaviors in some, and those in turn produce more concious and subconscious behaviors.
author: Roman Meneghinister

text: Â @BBÂ  I understand that it can be frustrating to have an argument just reduced to oh you're this or you're that. It sucks and feels like you aren't being heard. I think it is a mistake to ignore the influence that colonialism has had and still does have. Is it the end all be all. No, life is complicated and there is so much that influences every little thing. However trying to remove deleterious ideas that pervade our society is a worthy goal.  I dunno, in my mind, I would prefer to try and ensure that a reason for something is not the result of colonialism and it's legacy. As members of the scientific community, is it not our duty to try and remove unknown variables. Racism is irrational and becomes an irritating variable that we have to take into account because of the nature of our history and culture. It is something that we just can't ignore as a possible if not probable factor for things due to the fact that it is an uncontrollable variable. I don't want to make you feel defensive or to try and shame you. We are human, and as a result we are always working to improve ourselves as individuals, I got my fair share of things to work on. It isn't something to be upset about just a hey, I should work on that.
author: Roman Meneghinister

text: Â @BBÂ  So are you saying that social achievements are less important than "science"? A lot of scientifical discoveries are "useless" or of very little use when they are first discovered. My own area of research currently is something I'd gladly label as "useless" in comparison to the impact this woman had, she actually saved lifes.
author: Giovanni Rafael

text: Â @BBÂ  Sorry, this is bs. People are racist(including many scientists) and there is a lot of evidence for it. Maybe you should stop seeing just your area as "science". There are thousands of works about racism and bias in human science. Also, human science has proven that scientists can never be fully unbiased because they are human beings that are molded by society. You say we "search for discrimination in every aspect of life, but discrimination is present in every aspect of life and there are several studies that talk about that. Try to educate yourself and stop being so uncomfortable. People who refuse to acknowledge their own racist bias are a huge obstacle in the anti-racism fight. We are all racist(me as a black person included) but we have the option to deconstruct our ideas and concepts.
author: Giovanni Rafael

text: Â @BBÂ  Dude, you're acting like things happen in a bubble. Everything is connected and influences each other and if you understood that aspect of the natural world of science itself, you would understand that culture and history affect people in profound ways. Why is it so much worse of an action to accuse someone of racism, then the possibility that people can be flawed individuals and products of the history and culture they come resulting in inherent bias or racism. It would be fantastic to live in a world where race isn't even thought of as it is a artificial categorization of people, however, we don't live in that world. We live in one where white european descendants have and to a large extent still do reserve more positions of power, wealth, and authority then people of color. If you sample people of various income and job backgrounds, you would expect to find that each income bracket or job would have a proportionally representative percentage of people from the demographics of the population, however that is not the case. People of color are more likely to fall into lower income brackets and that isnt accidental, it is the result of policies and preferential treatment by companies and government agencies whose ideologies dated back to segregation. The foundation for segregation and jim crow laws are inextricably linked to the ideology of the trans atlantic slave trade. Policies and laws and actions taken from a fundamentally illogical system because race is a bad way to categorize people because it is fundamentally artificial. You have to keep in mind punching up vs punching down in terms of power and affects on people. I have to ask you, is it possible that people can be products of their culture and upbringing, that they can have intentional or unintentional bias in their actions. I dont think anyone here is denying the accomplishments people have made or that these are people who are undeserving of what they have accomplished. All that is asked is to recognize that people can and often times are flawed, and that we should always look out into the world and celebrate wonder, celebrate things that bring us hope, that tickle that itch in your mind to learn more or to see what can be accomplished when people ask a question or put their mind to things. When it comes to science, anyone can make a difference if they have that desire, that itch, and i think we should celebrate when people follow through with it.

the most obvious piece of evidence for me as a chemistry guy
is that Carbon has 3 common isotopes, Carbon 12, Carbon 13 and Carbon 14
in nature: C12 makes up some 97% of carbon found , C13 accounts for about 1% and  C14 for about 1 in a trillion Carbon atoms

C02 released by man has an isotopic fingerprint rather different to natural carbon
most fossil fuels are ultimately derived from old plants
but plants actually have an isotopic preference they prefer light atoms
so the burning of fossil fuels has a carbon ratio similar to a tree filled with lighter atoms

Carbon 14 is actually radioactive, and since oil is old as hell
it has Zero C14 since all C14 has decayed away by the time it becomes oil, even thoe C14 is only 1 in a trillion atoms
because there is so many atoms everywhere, u should expect a few hundred in every breath, making them easy to detect
which means having acutally 0 is really weird

because of this, we have been able to watch the Carbon Ratio in the atmosphere change over time
the typical carbon ratio in the atmosphere now, is basically that of a tree
we know of zero other processes in existence that can create this ratio...
and it coincidentally started about the time we developed cars...
and this ratio has not been found to exist in the atmosphere during any other time period
so we dont even have president to think its possible without humans


not to mention...  this was a prediction
someone said it would change the isotopes in the atmosphere like this decades ago, and now it has
predictions like these, lend ideas the highest credibility possible in science 

this is just the piece of evidence I understand the most as a chem guy
and alone, its the chemical fingerprint of man on the atmosphere 
this means that even if its not all  us, it is undeniably part  us

text: I don't understand how planting trees can help the climate. Trees don't store CO2, there are turning atmospheric carbon into organic carbonic compounds aren't they?  But when they die they these organic compounds are liberated partly to the atmosphere (CH4) and partly to the biological cycle by feeding other organisms that will eventually die themselves and so on. This carbon is not stored. Storing means that it is not available anymore for the carbon cycle (by burying it, or storing it into mineral forms (forming limestone for exemple). Life is not a way to store carbon because it decays quickly; it is just a step in the cycle. I don't understand.

(Also back in the Carboniferous fungus had not yet evolved ways to rot cellulose that helped to form carbon).  Humans can turn wood into furniture and bulding materials that with the correct maintenance can store the carbon for hundred of years.  So if you grow trees in a sustentable way, replacing the ones that you cut/die with new ones and avoid the rotting you are eliminating CO2.

text:
How are you going to quit using fossil fuels? The elephant in the room that these so called "science" shows never mention is every facet of our Lives is based on fossil fuels and technology is derived from fossil fuels. It is the reason why we are a growing population (humanity as a whole) and it is the reason we are not all farmers today as was once common just a few hundred years ago,  The reality is the food we eat was predominantly fertilized with fossil fuels.  The clothes you wear are either made directly from fossil fuels or grown using fossil fuels. We heat our homes with fossil fuels through the cold winter months (and it is because of fossil fuels we haven't cut all our forests down ironically enough). We transport our goods that we all require or consume with fossil fuels. Our infrastructure is refined using fossil fuels. Even energy efficient things such as energy efficient insulation is made either made directly from fossil fuels or made from consuming fossil fuels.  The computers we are currently using are made from fossil fuels and materials that were harvested using fossil fuels. Our transportation even when electrified is still fossil fuel derived for most of the world.   My point is there is no way to get away from using fossil fuels with the exception of becoming a hunter gatherer which the earth can not sustain 7.6+ billion people (and growing) living that lifestyle. 
About the only realistic thing you can do is reduce your personal consumption of non renewable resources by using things all the way to the end of thier life cycle (such as a cell phone or automobile as two great examples) and purchasing things that are locally sourced (no more exotic fruit/food for example that was imported from 1000s of miles away). 
Solar isn't realistic for most people and nor is wind, geo thermal is only possible for a few select places and fission nuclear waste although pretty clean the waste will all live every society in the world quite possibly combined. Fusion has yet to make a net energy gain and Probably will not for the foreseeable future. 
Don't fall for this doom and gloom predictions instead get into an energy related field and advance efficiencies of the above mentioned systems and quit watching these doom and gloom predictors that have yet to get anything right on their prophecies.
