text:
Doing something is easier than stopping doing something. Taking up smoking is easier than quitting. So, while the best way to stop climate change is to stop pollution, that would cause negative effects on the economy and would never be feasible.

Planting more trees, developing new green technology, and cleaner energy attract customers, as well as fixing climate change. That's why I believe we need to focus on cleaning the air moreso than stopping pollution entirely (of course, every small amount a company can stop polluting is amazing).

There's already "solar trees" out there in China that can capture CO2 better than trees can. There's already a method of extracting electricity from plants performing photosynthesis without harming the plant or soil (a newer green method of producing electricity called PLANT-E, look it up and check it out). We need to come up with more of these ideas as well as increasing sales and efficiency of these ideas.

Also, we should probably focus on Methane and SF6, which are much more potent than CO2.

author: Santiago Plazas

text: Â @Santiago PlazasÂ  thats one of the main reasons I said it can really only happen in certain locations, ideally they need a strong river going through a canyon without alot of people around. That's why there are a ton of them in places like the Columbia river and Colorado river. The space constraints dont matter as much with canyons because it's really easy to make the artificial lake taller rather than wider and you can more easily do multiple dams in series, which generates more power vs area and water. The ecological effects can be easily minimized by installing fish ladders and similar systems. There are smaller dams that dont require alot of area or large retention ponds but you just dont get nearly the return on investment, they're smaller, and theyre less predictable since they cant store as much power. Dams are also an issue in that there just isnt that many rivers that can be easily dammed since you really need some mountain pass, gorge, or similar natural formation to butt your dam against and to act as a retention lake AND it had to be a decent sized river. Those 2 traits alone disqualify most of the planet since you usually have a major river in a flat area (like the Mississippi) or you have a weak river near its source in the mountains. Then theres still the transmission problem since most cities arent built near large gorges in the mountains, they're usually near the coast or a plain

text: I work as an archaeologist in the wilds of the Internmountain west.  I see nature, utilities, and forestry companies planting lots and lots and lots of trees.  Trees grow up and die, then decay, slowly releasing the carbon harvested from the air.  From my work I also know that our species throws away trash at an epic scale.  In the old days, we just burned it.  Now trash, including wood products, gets encapsulated in land fills along with plastic bags. The combination is effective in stopping CO2 from escaping.  Mega, mega tons of paper and cardboard gets encapsulated.  However, Libraries and offices also archive a lot of paper and wood gets archived in buildings.  I decided to research the topic and realized that even with all the paper products archived, without stopping the burning of coal, it just won't matter.  I then discovered corn in the American midwest played a major role in removing carbon from the atmosphere. These crops also provided far more oxygen than is lost by Amazon deforestation (Yeah, I was suprised by this)  The CO2 harvested in the corn gets put into the consumer cycle as a variety of product such as corn syrup.  Consumed in soft drinks, the sugar gets metabolized by our bodies and released back into the atmosphere as CO2, though a portion gets archived as weight gain in our bodies.  A new CO2 cycle!

author: Barking Sheep

text:
Yes, mature forests have hit their sequestration equilibrium point. Cutting those section will undoubtedly release some of that stored carbon, but it also frees up the capacity of that land for new growth and further sequestration. 
As long as much of the carbon in the harvested biomass does not return to the environment and the trees are replanted, then the forestry industry is a huge contributor towards the carbon sequestration effort. Two ways this carbon can be kept out of the environment are through producing Lumber products and charcoal soil enrichment, by first pyrolysing forestry wastes.
It should also be noted however that harvesting wood removes not just the carbon, but also many nutrients and minerals from the soil, so repeated harvestings may deplete the soil of some vital nutrients, which may need to be monitored and balanced.

text: How planting the trees can make climate worse: plant them in the natural dry grasslands (steppes, etc). Roots of grass in the natural dry grasslands are huge (so-called "forest upside down") and contains huge amount of carbon dioxide. People planting trees there, trees degradates or burn out, as sites are not suitable for the trees and becoming even less suitable due to the changes of climate, and ecosystems of grasslands are also destroyed. Result: more carbon dioxide in atmosphere. This is what actually happens in southern Eastern Europe, particually in Ukraine: international "Kyoto" money are given to plant trees in Ukraine, they planting it in the natural steppes (of high conservation priority with tons of endangered steppe endemics), destroying it, in the few years there is no forest either, and they planting it AGAIN. Better made a video about this, that trees should be planted where they were naturally growing before, not in naturally forestless habitats. And native trees, as they often planting INVASIVE trees, not suitable for native biodiversity, American Robinia pseudoacacia in Europe, etc.

text: Â @Silver SurferÂ  When you look at plants, or a forest, realise that is made up of mostly hydrogen and carbon. The hydrogen it gets from water through the roots, the carbon through the leaves, from CO2. So it is obvious more CO2 is consumed than released. CO2 is the base of all life on earth. By photosynthesis, using the energy from the sun, water and CO2, is used to create carbohydrates. The whole food chain starts with this.
author: Rutger de Kok

text:
Â @Silver SurferÂ  Trees do not  suck CO2 at day and release the same amount at night. What they do is convert the CO2 into useful energy for them to grow via photosynthesis and reject some of the CO2 at night so the amount they release at night is very low compared to what they consume!

And no when you trees are planted there will nost just be trees it will develop an entire exosystem consisting of grasses and bacterias that also consume CO2 from atmosphere

text:
â€‹Â @Brandon WoodÂ  Agriculture is one of Michigan's economic pillars. Apples, asparagus, cucumbers, the type of onion most farmers grow, any corn (sweet or otherwise), 29 or 30 out of 30 types of blueberries, all of the types of bean the state produces, cabbages, carrots, celery, the two (economically) largest cherries, chestnuts, cranberries, grapes, peaches, pears, the four types of plum grown, potatoes, pumpkins, squash, raspberries, blackberries, probably the type of strawberries (I couldn't find that specific information, the closest I got was the state's favorite, which isn't native to the state), sugarbeets (used for Michigan's surprisingly strong sugar production), tomatoes, and wheat are not native to the state, so that's nearly the entirety of the crop side of the state's agricultural industry. And yet the state isn't facing an ecological calamity in counties with large swaths of farmland.

text: The problem is, hemp decomposes quite quickly, releasing all CO2 back into the atmosphere, whereas trees keep it captured for decades as they grow, and then for several more years as they decompose slowly. Or turn into fossil fuels, if left undisturbed in an ideal environment for several million years. If we could grow hemp and somehow prevent the decomposition, it might work though, but what could we use so much hemp for? The market for textiles and ropes is only so large. The usage in plastics and concrete is interesting though and offers more possibilities, but it needs to get viable first.

Â @ÃdÃ¡m ZovitsÂ  Fungi for car parts is in R&D, and soybeans for John Deere combine parts have been out for a while. Both fields, and others I haven't seen vids for, could be viable ways to sequester for years to decades. Not a long-term solution, but help. And we need all the help we can get.

For the past few hundred million years since bacteria learned to break down lignin and tree cellulose we won't even get more fossil fuels. Fossil fuels are a one time only, limited quantity, single use deal that can only be found on earth. Plenty of ethane, methane, and other hydrocarbons out there in The Universe, but fossil fuels like coal and oil are a one shot.

text:
"It's to be smart"

Until you point out the fact that 80% of the planet's oxygen is produced by plankton.

The reality is TeamTrees is an unorganized mess that doesn't actually have any impact at all, and if YouTubers had the balls to tackle climate change they would get political and endorse specific Democratic politicians that would force necessary regulations against fossil fuels, which would mean tackling the issue of corruption and Fossil Fuel lobbyists, which would get into endorsing (very specifically) Bernie Sanders to end the USA's fossil fuel emissions. That's not kumbaya, and we like to think "no matter what your beliefs are we can make a difference!". Reality says you can only really have one. Elect any other Democrat, and they'll let special interests run rampant until the US elects another Republican that will undo everything. This is the real solution to climate change, it's miserable and depressing politics; "I'm right and you're wrong", not "happy fun time let's all plant trees together".

Replacing all this land that's generally deforested for a reason with trees will (best case) literally bank up the CO2 until we need more trees again for the continual flow of CO2 into the atmosphere. It's the dumbest approach.
